title: England U21 5-1 Austria U21: Eddie Nketiah grabs hat-trick and misses penalty
text:
A triumph for England's trialling, Austria were demolished by the tinkerers on a night that will prompt real optimism.

This Under-21 squad have only been only been together for two camps, using them to try different styles and find fresh ways of playing. It also helps when your No 9, in this case Eddie Nketiah, bags a poacher's hat-trick.

This was evidence that altering formations – they played three separate styles – should work moving forward. After all, Austria are supposed to be England's main threat in a European Championship qualifying group the Young Lions are now in complete control of.

Callum Hudson-Odoi celebrates scoring England's first against Austria U21's on Tuesday night

Eddie Nketiah celebrates scoring the second during the Under-21 Championship Qualifier

Hudson-Odoi points to the sky having added a fourth for Aidy Boothroyd's side at MK Dons

MATCH FACTS England U21: Ramsdale, Justin, Guehi, Kelly, Aarons, Willock, Davies, Foden, McNeil, Nketiah, Hudson-Odoi. Subs: Balcombe, Panzo, Sessegnon, Richards, Wilmot, Skipp, Brewster, Gallagher, Surridge. Austria U21: Ehmann, Malicsek, Danso, Maresic, Friedl, Demaku, Lovric, Arase, Baumgartner, Meister, Raguz. Subs: Helac, Borkovic, Halper, Lema, Muller, Grull, Meisl, Golles, Schmidt. Referee: Michael Fabbri (Ravenna)

Aidy Boothroyd will view this as a significant step in the right direction. It was four by half-time, Callum Hudson-Odoi and Nketiah both scoring twice.

Hudson-Odoi's second was a peach, bending into the far corner after the Chelsea winger had picked up possession 30 yards from his own goal. The four England runners who kept up with him drew Austria all over the place.

Leeds loanee Nketiah's were predatory and the sort of finishes we have come to expect from someone who leans on Ian Wright for wisdom.

The first, however, will give Boothroyd the most pleasure. Their expansive 3-5-2 allowed Max Aarons to gallop on the right, collect Lloyd Kelly's searching diagonal, and cross for Hudson-Odoi to rattle in on the volley. His stay with the Under 21s may be short-lived.

Callum Hudson-Odoi, stop that.



⚡️⚡️⚡️



He's wasting absolutely no time on his return from injury! pic.twitter.com/ra9qVwuY4H — Football on BT Sport (@btsportfootball) October 15, 2019

Their only blot came after the hour, Christoph Baumgartner nestling between central defenders to find Aaron Ramsdale's corner.

England really ought to have plundered more before and after that consolation, Phil Foden's influence growing greater as the game became stretched.

Captain Tom Davies was denied on the line when attempting to turn in Foden's free-kick. The Manchester City midfielder – shortlisted for the Golden Boy award – then picked a tiny lock, only for Fabian Ehmann to thwart Joe Willock.

Ehmann expertly tipped Foden's wicked 30-yard free-kick over the bar, unfortunate not to cap another peerless display with a goal. Nketiah notched his third late on, finishing off Rhian Brewster's teasing cross. There remained time for the Arsenal striker to miss a penalty, but he won't mind too much.

The Arsenal youngster on loan at Leeds adds a third for his side and his second of the game
description: JACK GAUGHAN AT STADIUM MK: A triumph for England's trialling, Austria were demolished by the tinkerers on a night that will prompt real optimism.
authors: Jack Gaughan For The Daily Mail
